title: Single- vs. Dual-Prompt Dialogue Generation with LLMs for Job Interviews in Human Resources
author: Joachim De Baer (IDLab, Universiteit Gent – imec, Belgium), A. Seza Dogruöz (IDLab, Universiteit Gent – imec, Belgium), Thomas Demeester (IDLab, Universiteit Gent – imec, Belgium), Chris Develder (IDLab, Universiteit Gent, Belgium)
relevance_why: The dual-prompt strategy and evaluation techniques discussed in this paper can inform methods for generating and assessing audio-visual content in dialog systems, similar to those used in job interviews.
background: The study investigates two methods for generating job interview dialogues using large language models (LLMs), assessing their quality in mimicking human conversation.
contribution: This paper introduces a dual-prompt dialogue generation method to solve the problem of generating convincing job interview dialogues, achieving higher quality as determined by LLM evaluations.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous dialogue generation methods typically used a single prompt approach which may not capture the dynamism of real conversations effectively.
technical_comparison.novelty: The dual-prompt method enhances interaction realism by assigning distinct roles to LLMs, allowing for fluid dialogue construction.

key_innovation: Utilizes a dual-agent framework where each agent (interviewer and candidate) has specific prompts, fostering more natural and engaging dialogue exchanges.
real_world_impact: Improves the generation of synthetic job interviews, potentially reducing the costs and increasing the efficiency of recruitment processes in HR.
limitations: No limitations explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.duel-prompt: **Dual-prompt** refers to a dialogue generation method that uses separate prompts for each participant in a conversation, enhancing the interactivity and realism of the generated dialogue.
